ACT
222
Referral to litigation due to dispute
The court will terminate the probate proceedings and refer the parties to litigation or proceedings before an administrative body if there are disputed facts between the parties on which some of their rights depend.
The court will act in the manner provided for in paragraph 1 of this article, especially if the disputed facts are:
1. on which the right of inheritance depends, especially the validity or content of the will or the relationship between the heir and the testator, on the basis of which inheritance is legally granted,
2. on which the size of the inherited part, the value of the necessary part or inclusion in the inherited part depends,
3. on which the justification of the exclusion of necessary heirs or the existence of reasons for unworthiness depends,
4. whether a person renounced the inheritance.
If in the above cases there is no dispute about the facts, but the parties dispute the application of law, the probate court will not interrupt the probate proceedings, but will discuss the legal issues in the probate proceedings.
The court will not stop the proceedings even in the case referred to in paragraph 1 of this article, if it concerns facts the existence of which is assumed by law, facts which are generally known, and if the disputed facts can be established on the basis of public or publicly certified documents, but based on the presumption of the existence of these facts, i.e. that the content of these documents is true, will issue a decision on inheritance, and the person who claims the opposite of the presumption will be directed to prove it in litigation, i.e. in administrative proceedings.
